properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of record-breaking hot temperatures is expected to continue. Time span: continuing into Friday, and Saturday over southern sections. Maximum Temperature Friday: 33 to 35 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 39). Maximum Temperature Saturday: 30 to 34 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 36). Minimum Temperatures: 17 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: Inland areas of Nova Scotia. Remarks: Cooler temperatures will occur along parts of the coast, where winds blow onshore. Temperatures will return to more seasonal values over northern Nova Scotia on Saturday, however, hot weather is expected to continue over southern areas. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-19T10:54:07-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather is expected. Timing: Friday through Saturday evening. The heat event may persist into Sunday. Maximum temperatures Friday: 31 to 33 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 40). Maximum temperatures Saturday: 32 to 35 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 40). Minimum overnight temperatures: 18 to 20 degrees Celsius. Locations: Gatineau. During times of high heat, your health or your family and neighbours' health can deteriorate rapidly. The ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux du Québec, in cooperation with Environment and Climate Change Canada, recommends that you protect yourself from the effects of the heat by taking the following actions: Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water per day. Follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; Avoid alcoholic beverages; If you can, spend at least 2 hours a day in an air-conditioned or cool location; Take at least one cool shower or bath per day, or cool your skin several times per day with wet towels; Limit physical activity; Wear light clothes. Be sure to: Never leave a child or a baby alone in a vehicle or a poorly ventilated room, even for a few minutes; Check on your loved ones, especially those who are vulnerable or living alone. If you have any questions regarding your health condition, call Info-Santé at 8-1-1 or ask a health care provider. In case of emergency, call 9-1-1. For more information, visit the Government of Quebec's Portail santé mieux-être at www.sante.gouv.qc.ca. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-19T11:24:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-18T19:25:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3319502149.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The record-breaking hot weather is expected to continue. Time span: continuing into Friday, with a break for the northeast on Saturday then returning heat for Sunday and into the start of next week. Maximum temperatures Friday: 32 to 37 degrees Celsius (Humidex 38 to 42). Maximum temperatures Saturday: 30 to 34 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 37). Minimum overnight temperatures: 21 to 24 degrees Celsius. Locations: New Brunswick. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate over New Brunswick for the next few days. Friday is expected to be the muggiest day, where Humidex values will be near 40 for much of New Brunswick, and some inland areas in the northeast (Bathurst towards Kent counties) could see Humidex values of 42. Areas near the Fundy coast will be generally cooler throughout the period. Cooler temperatures are expected over northeastern parts of the province on Saturday, with a resurgence on Sunday and into next week. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 27 degrees Celsius are expected. Above normal temperatures and high humidex values will continue in the Kugluktuk area before coming to an end overnight tonight. Today's daytime high temperature will approach 26 degrees Celsius with a humidex of 29 degrees. The current record high temperature for Kugluktuk on June 18 is 26.7 degrees Celsius, set in 1935. Records for this area began in 1930. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 8:31 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. The storms are moving east northeast at 50km/h. ### Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-06-19T03:19:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-19T00:32:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2258515476.2020
Area: Webequie, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. Hazards: - Damaging wind gusts of 90 km/h - Nickel size hail Timing: This afternoon into this evening. Locations: Portions of far Northern Ontario including Pickle Lake, Fort Hope and Lansdowne House ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Locally heavy rain is also possible. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-06-19T12:24:15-00:00
